Dear Senator [Name], 

I am writing to voice my opinion about who should be chosen to serve as the President of the United States. In recent years, there has been much debate regarding whether the election should be determined by the popular vote or by the Electoral College. After some research, I believe that the Electoral College should remain. 

According to the texts, the system of the Electoral College was created as a compromise between Congress and the popular vote. This provides an additional layer of checks and balances in the process of electing a president. As a voter, I want to ensure that the best possible candidate is chosen. When multiple tests are conducted, it allows for a more accurate assessment of who should be elected. 

I agree with the author of the second source that there have been many presidents who have desired to abolish the Electoral College. This could be, as the author suggests, because they have lost the popular vote but still won the Electoral College. It is possible that these presidents wanted to get rid of the Electoral College to support their own agenda. This further supports the need for the Electoral College to remain in place, as a way to ensure that the election is fair. 

In regard to the 2000 fiasco mentioned in the second source

Dear Senator _________,

I am writing to urge you to support either abolishing the electoral college system or changing it to election by popular vote for the president of the United States. In its current form, the electoral college is unfair, has too much room for failure, and denies many states the opportunity to see the candidates. 

First and foremost, the current system does not allow us to directly vote for the president. We are, instead, voting for an elector who would then vote for the president. This may not be a problem for many people, but it leaves others feeling powerless. I believe that the power to elect the president should be in the hands of the people, not those of a select few. 

Moreover, the electoral college system has too much room for failure. Electors have been known to betray the will of the people, leaving the power of the election in the hands of a few. Furthermore, there is always the possibility of a tie, in which case the House of Representatives would choose the president, again denying the people their right to decide. 

Finally, the current system silences many smaller states. In many cases, the candidates do not even bother campaigning in these states, as their votes do

Dear _______,

I am writing to you today to urge you to consider replacing the current system of choosing our President through the Electoral College with a direct popular vote system. This change is necessary to ensure that the electorate of our country is given a true voice in deciding the leadership of our nation.

The Electoral College, while it has served us well for over two hundred years, is outdated and fails to truly represent the will of the people in many ways. For example, one elector in a small state carries the same weight as fifty-five electors in the most populated state. This disproportionate representation leaves many states without the same power in choosing a President that others enjoy. Additionally, this system allows for the possibility that the popular vote could be overridden, as seen in the 2000 election when Al Gore won the popular vote, but George W. Bush won in the Electoral College. This negates the impact of citizens’ votes and silences their voices.

A direct popular vote system is the most logical, fair, and just way to choose our President. It would give a voice to every voter in the country, putting the power back into the hands of the people. It would free the citizens of our nation from the tyranny of the minority

Dear Senator [Name],

As an American, I believe it is my right to have my voice heard in the election of our nation’s president. Unfortunately, I believe the current system of the Electoral College is taking away this fundamental right. The Electoral College is outdated, unfair, and fundamentally flawed. For this reason, I urge you to support changing the system in favor of electing the president based on popular vote. 

The current Electoral College system is unfair to the people of this nation because it takes away our right to decide who will be our country’s leader. In the 2000 election between Al Gore and George W. Bush, Gore had more popular votes than Bush, but still lost due to receiving fewer electoral votes. This is a prime example of how the Electoral College takes away the people’s power to decide who will be our president. 

Furthermore, the Electoral College has led to the potential for disaster. In 1960, the segregationists in the Louisiana Legislature attempted to hand pick electors who they believed would be opposed to John F. Kennedy. If this attempt had succeeded, the result could have been disastrous. Additionally, in 1960, Hawaii sent a conflicting set of electors to Congress, creating uncertainty and the potential for

Dear Senator of the United States,

I am a student from Miami Senior High School and I have been learning about the Electoral College Vote and its effects on our nation. After researching the issue further, I believe that the Electoral College Vote should be abolished and replaced by election by popular vote for the President of the United States.

The Electoral College Vote is unfair to the citizens of the United States, as it does not give us direct access to pick the President we want. Thanks to the quirks of the Electoral College, candidates may win the popular vote but lose the election due to the Electoral College, with 60 percent of voters preferring direct election. The Electoral College Vote also skews the voting towards swing states, as candidates spend more time in states that can influence their chances of winning, rather than equalizing the election and giving each state a fair amount of attention.

Bob Dole also supports the idea of abolishing the Electoral College Vote, arguing that this system is unfair to the citizens of the United States. Although the Electoral College Vote does give a more balanced representation than a pure popular vote system, this is offset by the fact that citizens are increasingly disenfranchised from the Presidential election. Even when Barack Obama received 61.7 percent of the Electoral Vote compared to

Dear Senator,

I am writing to argue in favor of changing the current system of electing the President of the United States from the Electoral College system to a system of voting by popular vote. I believe this change will be beneficial for our nation and the people of this state.

The current system of selecting a President is outdated and disadvantages many people. When citizens cast their votes for President, they are actually voting for electors pledged to their chosen candidate. This system of “electors” is both confusing and cumbersome. Furthermore, it is the electors, and not the popular vote that ultimately decides the election. This system is clearly unfair as it gives more power to certain regions of the country over others and can lead to the election of a President who has not earned the majority of the popular vote. This was the case in the 2000 presidential election, when Al Gore received more individual votes than George W. Bush nationwide, yet Bush won the election by a margin of 271 electoral votes to Gore’s 266. 

The current system has further disadvantages. For example, state legislatures are responsible for selecting electors, and these electors can be anyone other than public office holders, potentially leading to electors that do not reflect the true desires of the people.

Dear Florida State Senator, 

I am writing to express my support for changing the way the president of the United States is elected from the current system of the Electoral College to a system of election by popular vote. My argument in favor of this change is based on evidence from multiple sources, including an article by Brad Plumer, which highlights several issues with the Electoral College system.

The current system of the Electoral College is complicated and inefficient, which is why Richard Nixon, Jimmy Carter, Bob Dole, and the U.S. chamber of commerce have all voiced their support for its abolishment. This system also produces “disaster factors” where the state legislatures are responsible for choosing electors, who could quite easily defy the will of the people. Additionally, when Americans cast their vote for president, they are really voting for electors, compromising their own choice of who they want in office. This is simply not fair or right. 

Furthermore, the Electoral College system is widely regarded as an anachronism, or an outdated practice, as it consists of an electoral system based on majority Republican beliefs. This means that Democrats and those of no party often feel disenfranchised and that their votes do not count, as the president elected is

Dear [Senator Name],

I am writing this letter to express my opinion on the issue of deciding the President of the United States through the Electoral College or by popular vote. While I understand why some people might prefer the popular vote, I believe that the Electoral College is the most organized and beneficial way to elect candidates.

The Electoral College ensures that the election is decided without confusion or the risk of a tie. Richard A. Posner states in his passage, “The winning candidate’s share of the Electoral College invariably exceeds his share of the popular vote” (Source 3, p. 15). This means that there is a clear winner, and no need to worry about recounting ballots or long delays due to a deadlock. Furthermore, the Electoral College ensures that no one region can swing an election, but that the candidate must appeal to people across the country. As Posner states, “No one region has enough votes to win an election, so the President has to be liked by other regions as well” (Source 3, p. 19). 

The Electoral College also requires candidates to gain the support of the people in swing states, since these are the states who can tip the balance in an election. Pos

Dear Senator,

I am writing to you to discuss the issue of the Electoral College versus the popular vote for choosing the president of the United States. As a representative of your state, I believe that you should consider the potential benefits of changing to election by popular vote and understand why it is necessary to replace the current system.

The Electoral College is not a democratic system. The electors who actually choose the president are chosen by each candidate's political party and do not represent the general population. Furthermore, the "winner-take-all" system in many states means that even if people cast their vote for the losing candidate, all the votes are still given to the winner. This is highly unfair and does not accurately reflect the popular opinion.

The popular vote is the most reliable and direct way of selecting the president. It ensures that every vote counts and that the candidate with the most votes wins. This is more in line with the overall democratic nature of our society and ensures that people have a stake in the outcome. Additionally, the popular vote eliminates the possibility of unreliable results due to quirks in the Electoral College system, such as what happened in the election of 2000 when Al Gore won the popular vote but still lost the election.

Finally, the

Dear [Name of State Senator],

It is my belief that the current system of electing the President of the United States, which is done through the Electoral College, should be abolished and replaced with a popular vote system. To make my case, I will explain how the current system is unfair, outdated, and allowing for potential disasters due to its convoluted nature.

To begin, the current system of the Electoral College is unfair to voters because it does not allow citizens to have direct control over who is elected President. As stated in "What Is the Electoral College?" by the Office of the Federal Register, "When you vote for your candidate, you are actually voting for your candidate's electors." This means that citizens are not directly selecting the President, but are instead choosing their candidate's electors, who will then cast their votes in the Electoral College. This convoluted system is not only outdated, but removes the direct power from the people.

Furthermore, the Electoral College also allows for potential disasters due to its structure. As noted by writer Dylan Plumer in "The Electoral College Is an Irrational Outdated System That Needs to Go," "The American people should consider themselves lucky that the 2000 fiasco was the biggest election crisis in a century—the system allows

Dear Senator,

I am writing to you to express my concerns with the current system of choosing our President and Vice President in the United States and urge you to consider either keeping the Electoral College or changing to an election by popular vote. The electoral college is outdated, irrational, and it puts the power in the hands of the government rather than the people.

First, the electoral college gets people frustrated with our government because they have to go and vote for another person to vote, yet they cannot ever be guaranteed that the elector they vote for will vote for the person they wanted. This can be exceptionally dangerous with smaller states, as one elector can represent up to 500,000 people and can therefore have a greatly amplified effect on an election. This means that a group of people could vote for a certain candidate but yet an elector can change their mind and the group of 500,000 are suddenly voting for someone they don't like. 

Another problem is that the electoral college gives too much power to legislative branch. For example, in 1960 segregationists in the Louisiana legislature nearly succeeded in replacing the Democratic electors to oppose John F. Kennedy, showing us that the legislative branch can create a biased slant in the election. This takes away from the power of the

Dear State Senator,

I am writing to express my support for changing to election by popular vote for the president of the United States, rather than continuing to use the Electoral College. After doing research and reading several sources, I have come to believe that this change is essential to ensure fair and representative elections.

At the most basic level, the electoral college is unfair to voters. Candidates focus on key "swing" states, which leaves many states feeling ignored and powerless. It is also reassuring to know that the popular vote will be the deciding factor, and that the will of the people is more important than the opinion of a few electors. The Electoral College is widely regarded as an anachronism, and the arguments in favor of it are not based in reality. Furthermore, the disaster factor shows that the election could be thrown into chaos if only a few votes shift in the right direction.

When you vote for a presidential candidate, you're actually voting for a slate of electors. But if the election was conducted through popular vote, the will of the people would be more influential. That is why I think it is so important to change the system. It will create more equitable and democratic elections, and it will reduce the power of the few

Dear State Senator, 

The Electoral College is an important process of selecting the President of the United States. While some argue that it should be abolished and changed to election by popular vote, there are several compelling reasons that make it necessary to keep the Electoral College intact. 

First, the Electoral College guarantees a certain outcome, rather than leaving the result of the election up to chance. By splitting the responsibilities between both the people and political party members, the Electoral College avoids the possibility of a tie that could occur with popular voting. According to source 3 “In Defense of the Electoral College: Five reasons to keep our despised method of choosing the President”, “The reason is that the winning candidate’s share of the Electoral College invariable exceeds his share of the popular vote”. Therefore, the Electoral College is the more reliable method.

Furthermore, the Electoral College eliminates any potential regional bias in the election. The requirement of transregional appeal ensures that each region has an equal opportunity to vote and that the candidate is informed about the interest and concerns of every region. As source 3 explains, “The Electoral College requires candidates to have a transregional appeal.” By doing this, the Electoral College avoids disenfranchising

Dear Senator [Name],

As your constituent, I am writing to urge your support of changing the selection process for the President of the United States to a popular vote system. The current Electoral College system is unfair, outdated, and irrational and should not be relied upon to determine our nation’s leader.

The Electoral College system is unfair in that it allows the popular vote to be effectively overruled. In a unique twist of democracy, it allows a person to be elected president even if he or she failed to win the nationwide vote. This happened twice in the last 16 years, most recently in 2016 when President Trump received nearly 3 million fewer votes than his opponent but still won the election.

The system is outdated because it was created over two centuries ago, at a time when our nation did not offer universal suffrage and data transmission was a distant dream. It was originally designed to provide balance between the interests of the small states and the large states, at a time when the population of the United States was much smaller and had fewer means to gather information about the presidential campaigns.

Finally, the system is irrational because it allows a state’s electoral votes to be determined by the majority of the state, even if the minority of

December 18, 2014

Dear State Senator,

As a concerned and voting citizen of our state, I am writing to urge you to support the change to electing the President of the United States using a popular vote as opposed to an Electoral College system. The Electoral College system is outdated, provides for unfair voting conditions, and fails to accurately reflect the will of the people.

The Electoral College system was established by the Founding Fathers in the Constitution. While this system was once a valid representation of the population at the time, there are now more than 350 million people in the United States, and the Electoral College system fails to accurately and fairly represent this population. In fact, according to sources, the Electoral College is “widely regarded as an anachronism.”

The Electoral College system also fails to accurately reflect the will of the people. Even if the majority of people in a state vote for one candidate, the Electoral College system awards all of the electors to the winner, leaving the votes of the people who do not win completely unrepresented. Additionally, the “winnertakeall” system disincentivizes campaigns from visiting or focusing on states where they have little to no chance of winning, which leaves

Dear Senator,

I am writing to express my support for changing the current method of electing the President to a popular vote system. While the Electoral College has been a part of our democracy since the founding of the nation, there are several reasons why it should be abandoned or altered in favor of a more equitable system.

First, the Electoral College is heavily weighted in favor of the most populous states. This means that residents of less populous states have proportionally less influence in presidential elections than those in more populous states. This is particularly unfair as the vote of one individual in a populous state carries more weight than the vote of multiple individuals in a less populous state. This imbalance further deepens the disparity between our democracy's haves and have-nots.

Second, the system of winner-take-all elections, which is employed in many states, makes it difficult for candidates to campaign in every state, and even in every region of the country. This is because they know that they will only win all of the state's electoral votes if they win the state as a whole. This means that candidates will often ignore less populous states, or even regions of larger states, in favor of campaigning in swing states or more densely populated areas. This skews the democratic

Dear Senator, 

As I have been watching many presidential elections in my lifetime, I am conflicted when it comes to the Electoral College. On one hand, it seems that it should work. On the other hand, however, I cannot help but think it is outdated and could be improved. After reading sources on both sides of the argument, I have decided that the Electoral College should be done away with in favor of a national popular vote for president. 

The historical evidence supports this idea, as shown in source two. In 2000, Al Gore won the popular vote, yet he lost the presidency. This indicates that the Electoral College does not necessarily make sure that the will of the people is reflected in the election results, as it should. In addition, if the popular vote is the sole deciding factor, then the people can be sure that the president they voted for is the same one elected. 

There is also a chance of Electoral College votes being tied and the House of Representatives deciding the results, as stated in source three. This could lead to the people not getting the president they wanted, and thus their will not being reflected in the election. Furthermore, the Electoral College system enables bias to exist, as larger states have more power to

Dear State Senator, 

The election of our country’s leader is a huge deal and I am writing to you regarding the Electoral College and why it should remain a part of our presidential election process. Keeping the Electoral College has its benefits ranging from providing balance to all states, encouraging presidential candidates to have regional appeal, and ultimately empowers the people of the United States. 

The Electoral College allows balance within our elections. It is unlikely for there to be a tie during the Electoral College vote because of the counter-balancing of the larger versus smaller states’ votes. This helps to ensure that all states are heard and taken into consideration when electing a President, providing stability to all regions and the nation as a whole. It is also argued that the Electoral College gives the Larger states a chance to balance out the amount of representation they have in the Senate, granting them a larger voice in the federal government. This balance is needed to prevent instability and not favor one region of the country over another. 

In addition to balance, having the Electoral College ensures that presidential candidates must have regional appeal to receive votes in order to win the election. Candidates must seek the vote of all states, most importantly, the ‘toss

Dear Senator,

I am writing to express my strong support for the immediate abolition of the Electoral College and a transition to a system of election by popular vote for determining the President of the United States. The current system of selecting Presidential candidates through Electoral College is both unfair and outdated, posing numerous risks and disadvantages to voters and our democracy.

First, the Electoral College is a system in which electors are selected to cast votes for a particular presidential candidate in states based on the results of a popular vote. However, these electors are selected without the participation of the voters, and there is no guarantee that they will abide by the popular vote of their state. Therefore, it is possible for the popular vote to be overturned, allowing a candidate to win the election without actually winning the support of a majority of the people. This is an injustice to the majority of voters who may have voted for a different candidate.

Furthermore, the Electoral College is outdated and ill-suited for our modern democracy. It has been in place since the nation's founding, and the population has grown drastically since then, but the system remains largely the same. This means that certain states, and therefore certain voters, are given disproportionately more power than others in regards to the selection of our

Dear State Senator,

I am writing to urge you to consider changing the voting system for the President of the United States from the Electoral College to a popular vote. The current system is outdated, unfair and rarely reflects the true will of the citizens, and I believe it is time for an update.

Under the current system, individual states are allocated a certain number of electoral votes based on their population, and whichever candidate wins the majority of the votes in that state is given all of the electoral votes for that state. This means that in states with a large population, citizens’ individual votes can essentially be cancelled out if there is a majority in the opposite direction, and states with a smaller population can have an over-inflated influence on the outcome. In the 2000 election, the Democratic candidate, Al Gore, won the popular vote but lost in the Electoral College due to a slim majority for the Republican candidate in a few key states. This large discrepancy between the popular and electoral votes demonstrates that the Electoral College is not an accurate representation of the people’s will.

In addition to being undemocratic, the Electoral College system can discourage voters from turning out in certain states, as one side may already have a strong lead in those areas

Dear Senator (Name),

I am writing to argue for the implementation of a popular vote for the President of the United States rather than the current system of the Electoral College. I believe that our current system of the Electoral College is an anachronism that unfairly represents voters and can lead to catastrophe. The arguments against popular vote are either illogical or inconsequential and we as a nation should pay no heed.

The biggest and most obvious problem with our current electoral college system is that it unfairly represents voters in the states. An example of this unfairness towards voters propagated by the system is that in the 2012 election between Obama and Romney Florida gave all of its electoral votes towards Obama when he only won 61.7 percent of the vote. This method completely exludes the opinion of the minority, that 48.3 percent of people in Florida who didn't vote for Obama got their opinion taken away because all of the electors were given to Obama by a small majority. A second unfairness to the voters is the attention taken away from any voter not in a swing state. In the 2000 election, seventeen states got no attention from the candidates whatsoever. This system gives undeserved attention to a few swing states which will decide the election because of our outdated

Dear Senator,

I am writing to speak in favor of keeping the Electoral College system for the election of the President of the United States. The Founding Fathers had long discussions about how to elect a president and they decided on the Electoral College as the best method. Despite its flaws, it is still the most efficient system for electing a president.

It is true that the popular vote system would eliminate some of the issues associated with the Electoral College. However, it is less certain that the overall outcome of a popular vote election would be more reliable than with the Electoral College. For instance, according to an article by Richard A. Posner, "each party selects a slate of electors trusted to vote for the party's nominee and that trust is rarely betrayed." This gives us more certainty that the results of the election are true, since the electors are chosen as a reliable representation of the party's nominee. Another argument for keeping the Electoral College is that it requires presidential candidates to have a trans-regional appeal, which is something that would not be necessary if a popular vote system were in place.

In addition, the Electoral College encourages candidates to focus on "swing" states, which are states most likely to have a close election result. This allows these

Dear State Senator,

I am writing to passionately advocate for keeping the Electoral College as the method of election for the President of the United States. I believe that the Electoral College offers safeguards to prevent errors caused by election by popular vote and that it can protect smaller states which would suffer from a lack of representation if a popular vote was in effect.

First of all, it is important to consider the rationale behind the creation of the Electoral College. Our founding fathers, widely thought of as wise and caring for the nation's best interests, put in place the Electoral College system as a safeguard against errors made by popular vote. In "In Defense of the Electoral College: Five Reasons to Keep our Despised Method of Choosing the President" source 3 by Posner, it is argued that the Electoral College helps to ensure that each party has put thought into choosing electors that are trustworthy and unlikely to betray the party. This argument stands up against the criticism that the Electoral College does not consider the individual voter's choice, because it shows that the electors themselves are chosen by conscientious consideration.

Our current system also takes into account the size of the states, protecting the smaller, less populous states from suffering from a lack of representation. In "The Indefensible

Dear Florida State Senator, 

I am writing today to urge your support for enacting a system of direct voting for the President of the United States, rather than maintaining the current system of the Electoral College. As a citizen of Florida who believes in democracy and the power of individual votes, I believe that direct voting is the most fair and equitable system for selecting the leader of our nation.

The current Electoral College system, whereby individual states are assigned electors who cast votes on behalf of the state, is flawed and undermines the principle of one-person-one-vote that underlies our democracy. According to The Indefensible Electoral College: Why even the best-laid defenses of the system are wrong, the Electoral College has led to the situation where the popular vote does not necessarily determine the election outcome. In at least five presidential elections, the candidate receiving the most popular votes has not been declared president. This is neither fair nor democratic. 

Moreover, the Electoral College allows “faithless” electors to cast votes on behalf of their state in contradiction to the outcome of the popular vote, as has occurred in at least three presidential elections. This undermines the very concept of democracy by allowing a small number of political elites to overturn the

Dear Senator [Name],

I am writing to you to discuss my views about the current system of presidential election in the United States. After careful analysis and consideration of the available information, it is my opinion that the current system of the Electoral College should be abolished, and that elections should be based on the popular vote.

As illustrated by source two from Bradford Plumer, the Electoral College has been a target for abolition for many years. This is because the current system makes elections too close to call, which could be catastrophic in some situations. Additionally, Richard A. Posner in source three says that the electors actually elect the president, not the voters. This means that the citizens of the United States do not actually have the power to make decisions for themselves, since it is the slate of electors who are making the decision. This is contradictory to the concept of democracy, and therefore cannot continue to be the standard for presidential elections.

On the other hand, source one from the Office of the Federal Register outlines valuable information regarding the founding of the Electoral College as a compromise. This is a point that must not be forgotten, as it highlights the concerns and debates of the Founding Fathers when the Constitution was being crafted.

Ultimately, it is my belief

Dear Mr. Senator, 

I am writing to express my opinion on the Electoral College process for electing the President of the United States. I believe this process should be abolished as soon as possible, and the decision should be made by the American people through a popular vote. 

While some may argue that the Electoral College is widely favored by the people, in reality, over 60 percent of voters would prefer a direct election to the kind we have now. As demonstrated by the Bush and Gore election, even though Gore received more votes than Bush from the American people, the fate of the election was decided by just 271 people who were selected to represent the states through the Electoral College. This undermines the opinion of millions of people who have voted, and shows how easily the outcome of an election can be swayed by a handful of individuals. 

Moreover, switching to a popular vote would help to eliminate the risk of a tie, which could lead to an unorderly process. In 1968, a change of votes from just 41,971 people would have tied the electoral votes due to the even number of 538 Electors. This exemplifies how fragile the system is, even when it appears to favor a certain candidate. 

The Electoral

Dear State Senator, 

I am writing to urge you to consider either keeping the Electoral College as the system of determining the president of the United States, or to move to a system of election by popular vote. As an American citizen, I believe that our voting system should always reflect the will of the people and that it is vital to ensure fairness and accuracy in the process. 

The current system of the Electoral College is based on the idea of having Congress members choose the person they deem best suited for the office of the president. However, this system does not necessarily reflect the will of the people, and people often do not get to vote for the president they want. As referenced in the article “What Is the Electoral College” by the Office of the Federal Register, there are 538 electors and each state has a different number of electors according to the population of the state. This means that some states have more of a say in the election than others, and can thus sway the outcome of the entire election.

In addition, the article “The Indefensible Electoral College: Why even the best-laid defenses of the system are wrong” by Bradford Plumer, discusses the concept of the winner-takes-

Dear Senator, 

I am writing to express my opinion on the debate between keeping the Electoral College or changing to an election by popular vote for the President of the United States. As a member of your constituency, I believe that the Electoral College is the right choice for this crucial decision.

The founding fathers established the Electoral College in the constitution as a compromise between election of the President by a vote in Congress and election of the President by popular vote of qualified citizens. This compromise has held for over two centuries and I believe that we should maintain it. The Electoral College consists of 538 electors, and a majority of 270 electoral votes is needed to elect the President. The people of the United States should consider themselves lucky that the 2000 fiasco was the biggest election crisis in a century. The Electoral College has been modified over time with changes such as under the 23rd Amendment of the Constitution, the District of Columbia is allocated 3 electors.

The Electoral College is beneficial in terms of promoting stability, avoiding conflicts, and understanding the nuances in regional politics. It is also efficient in keeping the election process from becoming chaotic or too complicated. Every four years on the Tuesday after the first Monday in November, the presidential election is held, and all Americans are well aware

Dear Senator PROPER_NAME,

I am writing to you today to discuss the Electoral College system and why I believe it should either be kept or changed to a popular vote system for electing the President of the United States. I believe that the current system is unfair to voters, ignores candidates in certain states, and puts too much emphasis on swing states.

First, the current system is unfair to voters because of the winner-take-all system in each state. Candidates only focus their campaign efforts on the "swing" states, leaving other states behind. This means that their votes are not taken into account and those people are not considered heavily in the elections process. This is not fair and should be changed.

Second, the winnertakeall method of awarding electoral votes includes the candidates, as we saw in the 2012 election, to focus their campaign efforts on the tossup states. This means that voters in those states are more likely to pay close attention to the campaign, know that their votes are more important, and are more likely to decide the election. However, this ignores other states who should have the same say as the swing states. Everyone deserves a chance to be heard and it is not fair to ignore certain states in a

Dear Senator [Name],

I'm writing to you today regarding the Electoral College process of choosing a President and Vice President of the United States. As a resident of [State], I am greatly troubled by the process of having the Electoral College vote instead of allowing the people of the United States to vote directly.

At the onset, allowing the citizens to have a say in electing their President and Vise President provides democracy at its finest. People are educated on the candidates and make their decision with the utmost care. However, with the current Electoral College system, the people lose out on being heard. Electors have more decision-making power than the people themselves. This creates a sense of inequality among the citizens as their voices are not heard in the true sense.

Furthermore, the current system takes away the right of the people to decide for themselves who they believe would be the best person to run their country. This is an utter disrespect to the citizens and to the country as a whole. Candidates focus only on the swing states and disregard the other states. Dear Senator [Name],

I am writing to express my support for keeping the Electoral College in place for the Presidential Election. Our Founding Fathers created this institution in order to provide a fair way for citizens to have a say in who they wanted to be president. It has many advantages over popular vote by ensuring there is no possibility of a runoff election, pushing the presidential candidates to have a transregional appeal, and providing a more certain outcome.

One key benefit of the Electoral College is that it helps us avoid the problem of neither candidate receiving a majority of the popular votes. For example, Bill Clinton only had 43 percent of the popular vote in 1992 but still won the majority of the Electoral College votes. This demonstrates the Electoral College is able to provide a more accurate representation of the will of the people.

Furthermore, the Electoral College requires the presidential candidate to be ‘everybody’s president’. This means that a candidate cannot heavily campaign in a particular region where they are the favorite and ignore the rest of the country. Instead, a candidate must be familiar and popular with a transregional audience. This makes for a better informed electorate and a more involved candidate who is aware of the concerns of voters from all over the country.

Because of this, citizens who voted for the losing candidate still have their votes essentially nullified.

Dear Senator,

I am writing to discuss the issue of keeping the Electoral College or changing to election by popular vote for the president of the United States. As an American, I believe that the Electoral College should be kept as is and not changed. 

First, Americans may feel that they deserve a more direct voting system for the president, but if the government’s decisions were left in the hands of the people, there would be chaos and anarchy. The Electoral College offers an equal share of power to Congress, Senate, and the American citizens. It also prevents votes from being cast for the wrong president. 

The popular voting system is also very flawed. It overlooks states with smaller populations and gives too much power to larger states. Thanks to the Electoral College, each state receives an equal amount of votes towards the president. If the popular voting system was the only option, then states with higher populations would outnumber smaller states. 

In conclusion, the Electoral College has its merits when it comes to fairness and power balance. If the popular voting system was the only option, then it would be unfair to states with small populations. I believe that the Electoral College should remain in place. 

Thank you for your time

Limiting car usage would bring many advantages to our communities, both in terms of reducing pollution and reducing congestion. Cities such as Bogota, Colombia and Paris, France have already implemented car-free days, where cars are banned from the streets. These days have had a dramatic effect on the surrounding areas, reducing smog and traffic. 

In Bogota, for example, parks and sports centers have bloomed, rush-hour restrictions have dramatically cut traffic, and new restaurants and shops have opened. This has been made possible by banning cars for just one day a week, which has had a significantly positive effect on the city. In Paris, a similar system was implemented. On Mondays, drivers with even-numbered license plates were banned from the streets, and then the next day, odd-numbered license plates were banned. This resulted in a 60% reduction in traffic in the capital of France, and after five days, all traces of smog had disappeared. 

Limiting car usage is a simple solution with many benefits. Not only does it reduce pollution and congestion, but it also encourages people to become more active by walking or biking to their destinations. It is also a great way to save money, both on fuel and on car maintenance.

The growing debate in the United States about the merits of the Electoral College as the system for electing the President has reached a fever pitch. On one side, there are those who believe that shifting to a popular vote system would be more democratic and more representative of the people’s will. On the other side, there are those who argue that the Electoral College is necessary in order to ensure that all states have a voice and are equally represented in the electoral process. After examining both sides of the issue, I conclude that the Electoral College should remain in place in order to protect the interests of both small and large states and preserve the delicate balance of power in our nation.

The Electoral College system is designed to grant each state a certain number of electoral votes based on its congressional representation. This system helps to protect the minority rights of smaller states and ensures that their concerns are not overshadowed by densely populated regions. By giving each state a voice, the Electoral College encourages candidates to campaign in a variety of different states, rather than focusing exclusively on highly populated urban areas. This ensures that candidates have a broad base of support across the country and promotes national unity.

The Electoral College also serves as a necessary safeguard to protect our electoral process from potential fraud or external interference.

As our cities continue to grow and urban life becomes increasingly congested, the need to limit car usage has become more evident than ever. While cars undoubtedly provide convenience and flexibility, there is a pressing need to move towards a more sustainable and environmentally friendly mode of transportation. By reducing our reliance on cars, we can enjoy numerous advantages for both ourselves and our communities, including improved air quality, reduced traffic congestion, and enhanced public health.

Body Paragraph 1: Improved Air Quality
One of the primary advantages of limiting car usage is the direct impact it has on improving air quality. Cars emit harmful pollutants into the atmosphere, contributing to air pollution and climate change. According to a study conducted by the American Lung Association (ALA), vehicle exhaust is a leading source of air pollution in urban areas. By reducing the number of cars on the road, we can significantly decrease the emission of greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide and nitrogen oxides. This reduction in pollution levels will not only benefit the environment but also improve the overall health and well-being of citizens, especially those suffering from respiratory conditions.

I am writing to you today to discuss the current system of electing the President of the United States. I believe the Electoral College should be removed and replaced with a system of popular vote. For example, in the 1960 election, segregationists in the Louisiana legislature nearly succeeded in replacing Democratic electors with electors who would oppose John F. Kennedy (Source 2, Paragraph 11). This demonstrates that an Electoral College vote can be manipulated to produce a result that is not based on the will of the people.

Additionally, the Electoral College system encourages a "winner-take-all" approach to campaigning. Candidates often focus their efforts on larger, more populated states, and ignore smaller states entirely. During the 2000 campaign, seventeen states did not see the candidates at all, including Rhode Island and South Carolina, and voters in 25 of the largest media markets did not get a single campaign ad (Source 2, Paragraph 13). This lack of representation leaves many voters feeling as though their voices are not being heard.

Dear State Senator, 

I am writing to urge you to maintain the Electoral College system for electing the president of the United States. The Founding Fathers established the Electoral College as a compromise between having the president elected by Congress and having the president elected by popular vote. This compromise has been in effect for centuries, and I believe that changing it now could have potentially disastrous consequences. 

First, when we vote for the people who represent us, they have the experience in the political arena necessary to make an educated decision on who should become president. They have spent years learning the ins and outs of politics, and so “the most thoughtful voters should be the ones to decide the election” (Paragraph 20). Additionally, as noted in Paragraph 16, “each party selects a slate of electors trusted to vote for the party's nominee”, which means that the people we select to represent us are trusted to make the same decision we would. 

Second, if the Founding Fathers established the Electoral College as a compromise in the Constitution, then it should be left alone. While some people may think it is a bad idea to have the Electoral College, if that is the system we have been using, it should not be changed.
